subject: host-state-manager: Add multi-host support
commitMessage:
host-state-manager: Add multi-host support

Add support management multiple host state with multi process.
Each process obtain a d-bus object for corresponding host.

TESTED : Built the openbmc image for Facebook Bletchley hardware.
Verified Host State buses/objects created successfully

root@bletchley:~# busctl tree xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host1
└─/xyz
  └─/xyz/openbmc_project
    └─/xyz/openbmc_project/state
      └─/xyz/openbmc_project/state/host1
root@bletchley:~# busctl tree xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host2
└─/xyz
  └─/xyz/openbmc_project
    └─/xyz/openbmc_project/state
      └─/xyz/openbmc_project/state/host2
...

Built with host id 0 :
expose both Host and Host0 name to keep backwards compatibility.
'busctl |grep xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host'
...
xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host   8398 phosphor-host-s root  :1.212  xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host@0.service
xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host0  8398 phosphor-host-s root  :1.212  xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host@0.service
...

Signed-off-by: Allen.Wang <Allen_Wang@quantatw.com>
Change-Id: Ie18007122a5df9e33f387e691eaa9979ce18ed0e

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 79b45003dc8caa96124e33c8cc398af0e8a5b9c9

If we're going to start adding optional arguments, I'd prefer we keep it consistent with what was done in discover_system_state.cpp and utilize getopt_long vs. custom command line processing (although we can just pass in the host instance here vs. the whole path like was done in discover_system).
Done
Please add a "%i" in the Description somewhere so we know which instance it's running for in the journal.
Done
Instance is hard coded here, not sure if you can add a %i there or not. Can be figured out in the future if preferred.

I had checked this object, its created by phosphor-settingsd, 
it can change to %i ,but note that it must add those objects into phosphor-settingsd by *.override.yml else service can't start because it is waiting  /xyz/openbmc_project/control/host<N>/auto_reboot forever...

Example:add settings objects into our platform:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/51703

Also, settings.hpp/cpp will need some change to parse correct setting object path,but I still work on this, maybe do another commit in future.
This was a trick to ensure the service was up and running but it shouldn't really be needed since we label this as a Type=dbus. You can probably just remove this.
Done
Note that since this is now a instance based service, it will need to be explicitly installed in the phosphor-state-manager-systemd-links.inc recipe.

Thanks, I create a commit to install instances,

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/51704
This is a good start, but I think there are still some details to be worked through to make things consistent for single-host and multi-host systems.

Rather than do all this modification, I would suggest that we set the strings to something like:

    "obmc-host-shutdown@{}.target"

Whereever we are currently interacting with the map, we can add a utility function where we pass the instance-id and replace the {} with the instance ID.

auto getTarget(size_t /* or const std::string& */ instance, server::Host::Transition state)
I think it doesn't need to perform format string every time? so I add maps as class member and format those target name strings by host id at constructor.
This is a global but you are modifying it with local (instance) values?  This means you cannot have two Host instances in the class.  Why doesn't this variable become a class member?
Done
Please add hostId parameter here too.
Done

I would suggest passing this as a integer (size_t).  The fact that it is convenient to have it as a string is an internal detail to this class.  If you want to store it as a string in the class that is fine.

I would also either recommend it be the first parameter or defaulted to 0.  You can just name it 'id'.  Host is redundant since this is a Host class.
Done
In the case where -h isn't given, doesn't this BUSNAME not contain '0'?  I think we need to fix that.
Done
I guess I see now why you've used std::string in the constructor; to minimize parsing.  Do we at least want to do some format checking to ensure that this contains only digits?
I just convert string to int and catch exception to check if input only digits, is there a better way？

What happens if someone calls like this?

    executable --host=5 --host=3 --host=2

Doesn't the hostbusname become "...532"?
Done
We should not supply both Host services.  If it is now templated, it should be templated for @0 also.
Done
You could simply `method.append(getTarget(tranReq))`.  The way you have it you end up with an unneeded string copy.  You could also avoid the string copy by setting 143 to `auto&`.
Done
It doesn't look like you're using `fmt/format.h` here, so just put it in the cpp part.
Done

small POD values should not ever have const on them.  It isn't part of the C++ name mangling so it is just noise in the code.

Generally we use `size_t` instead of `std::size_t`.  Does this not compile?  You might need `#include <cstddef>`.
Done
These should both be `const std::string&` so the caller can't modify your tables.
Done
prefer plain `size_t` here.
Done

There is also std::out_of_range possible here.  I don't think you really need to catch this though.  Just let the top-level std::terminate trigger.  The silent failure you're doing is actually worse than the exception message printed by std::terminate.
Done

PLEASE DO NOT MERGE this patchset:

This patch will change HOST0 busname to "xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host0",
however we noticed there are many services/packages hardcoding host busname to "xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host", we are afraid of some single-host platform will broken.

Because its too hard to modify everywhere hardcode busname for now...,we'd like to keep the bus name of HOST0 to original "xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host" instead of change to "xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host0" at next patchset, how will you suggest for this?
Just a minor nit on the default initialization.  Otherwise looks good to go to my eyes.  Thanks Allen!
Thanks for your helpful suggestions!
it seems id won't change, could we make it const?

Also prefer default initialization on it: `size_t id = 0`.

I'm not too concerned on the constness but you're welcome to make that change.

Same as Potin replies at chassis state manager ,I thought member initializer list will initialize this variable, or should we add default value to constructor parameter at line 56?

Host(sdbusplus::bus::bus& bus, const char* objPath, size_t id = 0) :

It can be an optional constructor parameter.  That is separate.

You should initialize it in the constructor when you have the value (ie. the constructor variant that has `id` as a parameter).  It is also good practice to add a sane default at the definition site.  This is good for maintainability if someone adds a new constructor and doesn't need to manipulate `id` for their constructor variant; the class will already have code to handle this because you've specified the default.

> It can be an optional constructor parameter.  That is separate.
> 
> You should initialize it in the constructor when you have the value (ie. the constructor variant that has `id` as a parameter).  It is also good practice to add a sane default at the definition site.  This is good for maintainability if someone adds a new constructor and doesn't need to manipulate `id` for their constructor variant; the class will already have code to handle this because you've specified the default.

I understand it, to set default value at definition ,user can add constructor without id parameter. (like the old one or some single host specific feature?)

> I understand it, to set default value at definition ,user can add constructor without id parameter. (like the old one or some single host specific feature?)

Yes.

This suggestion isn't necessarily about this particular class, but a general principle that should be followed in C++ code.  Modern C++ should have a default value for every member, if possible.
